ObjectClass.preferredName: Radical Prostatectomy Gleason Score for Prostate Cancer

The two types of radical prostatectomy are retropubic prostatectomy and perineal prostatectomy.:The score derived from universally embraced prostate cancer grading system developed by Dr. Donald F. Gleason in 1977. The system provides a reproducible description of the glandular architecture of prostate tissue to which a pathologist assigns a score d

Concepts.definition: The surgical removal of all of the prostate as well as some surrounding tissue, including lymph nodes.

The score derived from universally embraced prostate cancer grading system developed by Dr. Donald F. Gleason in 1977. The system provides a reproducible description of the glandular architecture of prostate tissue to which a pathologist assigns a score depending primarily on the microscopic patterns of cancerous glands and cell morphology. The system correlates well with behavior at the extremes: Gleason 1+1 tumors are the most well differentiated, slowly growing and rarely spread; Gleason 4+5 tumors are the most poorly differentiated, often widely metastatic at the time of diagnosis. In the commoner intermediate grade tumors, however, behavior is extremely variable.

Property.preferredName: Tertiary Gleason Score for Prostate Cancer

Concepts.definition: Prostate carcinoma patterns occupying less than 5% of the tumor.
